Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story: I stood at the edge of the crowd, my younger brother beside me, his hand gripping mine tightly. The demonstration was loud, passionate, and tense. Suddenly, a group near us began urging everyone to step past the police barricade, claiming it was the only way to make our voices heard. My brother looked at me, his eyes wide with uncertainty. As his sister, I knew he expected me to guide him, to show him how to handle conflict and misunderstandings with respect and open communication. I wanted to set an example, to help him see that we could stand up for what we believed in without disrespecting others. But as a citizen, I also felt the weight of the law pressing on me—the expectation to respect public property and the rights of everyone, even those on the other side of the barricade. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the urge to support my brother’s desire to be heard and my responsibility to uphold the law. The crowd’s shouts grew louder, and I felt torn, caught between being the sister he needed and the citizen I was supposed to be.
